title: Aeneid 1 747-754 - Dido falls in love - Set 2

content.question:
Ingeminant plausu Tyrii, Troesque sequuntur.

Nec non et vario noctem sermone trahebat

infelix Dido longumque bibebat amorem,

multa super Priamo rogitans, super Hectore multa;

5nunc quibus Aurorae venisset filius armis,

nunc quales Diomedis equi, nunc quantus Achilles.

"Immo age et a prima dic, hospes, origine nobis

insidias" inquit "Danaum casusque tuorum."

Aeneid 1. 747-754

Answer the following questions in English unless the question specifically asks you to write out Latin words. Number your answer to each question.

1. In lines 1-4 (Ingeminant . . . multa), (A) identify the one present active participle and (B) identify one of its direct objects.

2. (A) Identify one and only one literary device found in line 2 (Nec . . . trahebat) and (B) write out the Latin word or words that illustrate it.

3. In lines 2-4 (Nec . . . multa), which three Latin words indicate that Dido had strong feelings for Aeneas?

4. In lines 2-6 (Nec . . . Achilles), identify the two Latin nouns that are genitives of possession.

5. (A) What are the case and use of nobis (line 7) and (B) to whom or what does it refer?

6. In lines 7-8 (Immo . . . tuorum), which two Latin words can be translated as “the treacheries of the Greeks”?

7. In this passage, Dido asks Aeneas about characters from the Trojan War. (A) In what situation earlier in Book 1 was he reminded of events from the Trojan War? (B) Briefly describe how he reacts to these reminders.

unit.text: 4: Teacher's Choice - Latin Poetry and Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 1 and 2

skill.text: 1.B: Describe how grammar contributes to the meaning and function of Latin words and phrases in context.
